Description: Semi-circular element carved from calcite; could correspond to a fragment of waste from vessel production; unfinished; one side smoothed, the other left rough.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Second Temple of Apollo (Naukratis), Between the temple and the north-west corner of the temenos (probably)
Curator's comments: If the identification of waste from the production of a vessel in calcite is correct, then this element could be associated with the production of calcite vessels well attested in Naukratis. Indeed, the early excavations at Naukratis provided much evidence for the mass production of vessels in calcite during the Late Period, likely in the 5th century BC and maybe already in the late 6th. Petrie noted that ‘many thousands of alabaster drill cores from tubular drilling’ as well as unfinished vessels in alabaster were found in the temenos of Apollo, between the temple and the north-west corner of the temenos (Petrie 1886, 15). The bulk of calcite vessels discovered in Naukratis are alabastra, but other shapes are present such as bowl, jug and lekythos. Petrie, W. M. F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I., 1884-5 (Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund 3), London. On Egyptian stone vessels and their production: Nicholson, P. T. and Shaw, I. 2000, Ancient Egyptian materials and techniques, New York. Aston, B. G. 1994, Ancient Egyptian stone vessels: materials and forms, Heidelberg. Petrie, W. M. F. 1974, Tools and Weapons, Warminster. http://www.oocities.org/unforbidden_geology/ancient_egyptian_stone_vase_making.html
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (EA.051) (phase 3)
